answer_html: \(\displaystyle \lim_{x \to \infty} e^{-x} - x\) diverges to \(\displaystyle -\infty\)
hints_html: What does the graph of \(e^{-x}\) look like? What happens to it as x goes to infinity?
hints_latex:
What does the graph of $e^{-x}$ look like? What happens to it as
\emph{x} goes to infinity?
hints_raw: What does the graph of <math>e^{-x}</math> look like?  What happens to it as ''x'' goes to infinity?
question: 1 (c)
sols_html:
We will consider the function inside the limit as the sum of two functions

\[\begin{aligned} e^{-x}\end{aligned}\]

and \(-x\). If we take their limits separately, we get:

\(\displaystyle \lim_{x \to \infty} e^{-x} = 0\)

\(\displaystyle \lim_{x \to \infty} -x\) diverges to \(\displaystyle -\infty\)

We can see that as x goes to infinity, the \(e^{-x}\) term is decreasing towards zero and the \(-x\) term grows larger and larger. So, as x goes to infinity the combined value of \(e^{-x} - x\) will grow more and more negative. Thus we have:

\(\displaystyle \lim_{x \to \infty} e^{-x} - x\) diverges to \(\displaystyle -\infty\)
